Award.AwardTitle: Cold and Possibly Unbound Planets from Wide-Field Microlensing Surveys
Award.AbstractNarration:
The PI and his team will continue to search for new exoplanets using gravitational microlensing techniques in collaboration with an international network of observatories with wide-field telescopes. Microlensing is a phenomenon which can be used to detect a very faint object, such as planet, through the planet's gravitational bending of light of a background source. The investigators will conduct observations with an international network of professional and amateur observers.

This work will have broad impact by involving researchers in different countries, by making progress in unifying the gravitational lensing community, working with amateur scientists at some of the telescopes, and public outreach efforts. The PI will also train a graduate student in this field. Microlensing has the potential to detect many new exoplanets with important demographics that are often missed with other techniques, such as finding planets at high separation from the host star, and free-floating planets, or those which do not appear to be gravitationally bound to any star.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project supported the MOA-II gravitational microlensing survey in its search for exoplanets orbiting distant stars in the inner disk and bulge of the Milky Way. This work included a lead role in the discovery of 14 new exoplanet systems and a supporting role in the discoveries of many others. All these planets orbit their host stars beyond the snow line, where planet formation is thought to be most efficient, according to the leading core accretion theory of planet formation. This gravitational microlensing method is only mehod sensitive to low-mass planets beyond the snow line, and a recent analysis by the MOA group including these 14 new exoplanets showed that Neptune-like planets are much more common than Jupiter-like planets beyond the snow lines. In fact, they are probably the most comon type of planet in the outer regions of planetary systems.

Our project also pioneered a new method to find planets in very wide orbits. Planets can be found in wide orbits even in cases where the microlensing signal of the host star is too feeble to be detectable. Instead, the properties of the host star can be inferred from the distortion of the planetary microlensing signal due to the gravitational field of the host star. The first example of such a microlensing event, MOA-bin-1, was found by this project.

This project also helped ot confirm one of the first exoplanets found by microlensing, OGLE-2005-BLG-169Lb. Hubble Space Telescope and high angular resolution observations from the Keck telescope found the image of the host star separating from the background source star at exactly the rate predicted by the planetary feature of the microlens model, implying that the planetary light curve interpretation is correct.

This project also supported the development of student Aparna Bhattacharya and postdoc Daisuke Suzuki, and the PI supervied the exoplanet microlensing modeling effort for the MOA Collaboration. Under this grant, the PI taught both Bhattacharya and Suzuki, as well as a half dozen other MOA collaoborators how to model planetary microlensing event light curves.
